title: 14 Beverages that Make You Poop Quickly

steps.title: Sip a glass of prune juice to clear away constipation.
steps.content: Sip a glass of prune juice to clear away constipation. In one particular study, frequently constipated individuals found that drinking 1 c (240 mL) of prune juice (or a placebo) daily over the course of eight weeks made their bowel movements a lot more consistent and easier to pass. So, the next time you need to completely empty your bowels, try drinking prune juice and see what happens—you might be pleasantly surprised! [1] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source The study’s researchers believe that specific ingredients in the prune juice, like polyphenols, dietary fiber, and sugar alcohol, helped clear away the constipation. Besides prune juice, some research points to apple and pear juice being helpful for constipation (especially for children). [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use Epsom salt as a natural laxative
steps.content: Use Epsom salt as a natural laxative by mixing it in a glass of water. Stir 2-6 exact teaspoons (10-30 g) of Epsom salt in an 8 fl oz (240 mL) glass of water. If you’d rather drink a smaller dose, divide the total dose in half, drinking two 8 fl oz (240 mL) saltwater mixtures at least 4 hours apart. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Feel free to squeeze a little bit of lemon juice into the water to counteract the salty flavor. [4] X Research source For kids, cap off the dosage at 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of Epsom salt per day. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Magnesium boosts the water content in your intestines, which can be a big help if you’re feeling blocked up. [6] X Trustworthy Source Michigan Medicine The University of Michigan's medical center, which provides patient care, supports research, and educates the public on health topics Go to source

steps.title: Take a dose of castor oil
steps.content: Take a dose of castor oil for quick relief. Follow the dosage instructions on the bottle—most include a spoon to help you measure it out. Castor oil causes your intestinal muscles to contract, which helps stool move more efficiently through your bowels. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Warning: Castor oil may negatively interfere with certain supplements like vitamin A, D, E, and K, so check with your doctor before you start taking this medication. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take a 2-4 tbsp (30-60 mL) dose of mineral oil once before bed.
steps.content: Take a 2-4 tbsp (30-60 mL) dose of mineral oil once before bed. [9] X Research source Mineral oil falls under the umbrella of “lubricant laxatives”—these are laxatives that surround the bowel movement in a type of waterproof film, which makes it easier for the poo to glide through your colon and into the toilet. [10] X Research source Only take a single dose of mineral oil per day and see how it works for you. [11] X Research source Always double-check your dosage instructions before taking this medication. Warning: Like castor oil, mineral oil may interfere with certain supplements. Check with your doctor before you give this treatment a try.

steps.title: Stir fiber powder into your drink to help speed up your bowel movements.
steps.content: Stir fiber powder into your drink to help speed up your bowel movements. Check the dosage instructions on the side of your fiber supplement and scoop the recommended amount into your drink. The fiber in this supplement makes your stool softer and bulkier, so it’s easier for you to have a bowel movement. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Psyllium and methylcellulose are both great fiber supplements to consider, as well a plant-based prebiotic fiber product .

steps.title: Using laxatives
steps.content: Using laxatives is a good last resort if nothing else seems to work. Follow the dosage guidance on the package of your laxative powder. Then, stir the recommended amount into a glass of water. Osmotic laxatives like Miralax help make your poop softer and easier to expel, while stimulant laxatives like Dulcolax help get your intestinal muscles to contract. Both are an effective means of speeding up your bowel movements. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Tasty combos of high-fiber ingredients may help get your bowels going.
steps.content: Tasty combos of high-fiber ingredients may help get your bowels going. Pour 1 ⁄ 3 c (79 mL) of aloe vera juice into a blender, along with 1 peeled kiwi, ½ cup (75 g) of papaya, 1 ⁄ 2 c (120 mL) of kefir (plain- or vanilla-flavored), and ½ cup (75 g) of ice. Blend everything together and drink a single serving each day. [14] X Trustworthy Source Michigan Medicine The University of Michigan's medical center, which provides patient care, supports research, and educates the public on health topics Go to source Berry Spinach Smoothie: Combine 1 scoop of ice, 1 c (240 mL) of apple juice, 1 c (240 mL) of Greek yogurt, 3 cups (95 g) of spinach, 2 cups of frozen or fresh blueberries (190 g), and 1 banana in a blender. Feel free to substitute raspberries or strawberries for the blueberries. Green Smoothie: Blend 1 cup (119 g) of chopped cucumber, 1 c (240 mL) of prune juice, and 2 cups (60 g) of raw spinach together. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Stir 1-2 spoonfuls of pruny paste into a mug of hot water.
steps.content: Stir 1-2 spoonfuls of pruny paste into a mug of hot water. Start by making 2 1 ⁄ 2 c (590 mL) of tea using 4 oz (113 g) of senna tea leaves . Strain the tea into a separate pot with 1 lb (0.5 kg) of prunes, 1 lb (0.5 kg) of pitted raisins, and 1 lb (0.5 kg) of figs. Bring the mixture to a boil for 5 minutes, and then take the pot off the heat. Add in 1 cup (213 g) of brown sugar and 1 c (240 mL) of lemon juice before blending everything together with a food processor and mixing a couple spoonfuls into some hot water. Feel free to snack on 1-2 spoonfuls of this paste each day, or use it as a spread on your morning toast. Transfer any leftover paste to an airtight container and stash it in the freezer as you use it up. Don’t worry—it won’t freeze into a solid block. Not noticing any results? Add a little more paste to your drink and see if you detect a difference.

steps.title: See if your morning cup of coffee sends you to the bathroom.
steps.content: See if your morning cup of coffee sends you to the bathroom. According to researchers, caffeinated coffee jumpstarts the muscles in your colon, which helps your intestines pass stool more efficiently. So, the next time you’re feeling blocked up, drink a cup or two of coffee. [16] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Mix 1-2 tbsp (15-30 g) of chia seeds into a 8–10 fl oz (240–300 mL) cup of water.
steps.content: Mix 1-2 tbsp (15-30 g) of chia seeds into a 8–10 fl oz (240–300 mL) cup of water. As a fiber-rich ingredient, drinking chia seeds helps add a lot of bulk to your poop as it passes through your colon, making it softer and easier to pass when you’re on the toilet. Just keep in mind that too much fiber can also block you up—so, take it easy when you first try a chia seed drink. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Eating around 25 to 30 grams of fiber a day is a good place for fiber intake. Two tablespoons of chia seeds nets you a little less 10 g of fiber, so you don’t have to go overboard! [18] X Research source

steps.title: Drinking a glass of aloe juice
steps.content: Drinking a glass of aloe juice may help you poop a little more easily. As the juice passes through your system, it actually makes your poop a bit softer so you don’t have as much trouble passing a bowel movement. As an added bonus, pure aloe vera juice doesn’t have a lot of calories or sugar, as opposed to other fruit juices you see in stores. [19] X Research source Have some raw aloe vera hand? Use it to make your own aloe vera juice .

steps.title: Drink kefir to speed up your bowel movements.
steps.content: Drink kefir to speed up your bowel movements. In one Turkish study, participants drank kefir regularly and noted how it affected their bathroom habits. Overall, people found that kefir helped them both pass softer stool and poop more frequently. If you don’t have any kefir on hand, feel free to make your own using kefir grains . [20] X Research source Additionally, a large-scale analysis of multiple British studies reveals that probiotics, in general, can help improve stool consistency and frequency overall. Not a fan of kefir? Try another probiotic-rich drink like kombucha and see if helps you poop more quickly.

steps.title: Brew yourself a cup of senna tea for its laxative effects.
steps.content: Brew yourself a cup of senna tea for its laxative effects. Pour some boiling water into a mug, adding in about 1-2 grams of senna tea. Let the tea steep for about 10 minutes before you drink. Try to limit yourself to 2 cups a day, though, so you don’t develop any unpleasant side effects (like diarrhea or abdominal pain). [21] X Research source There’s not a lot of concrete research about senna tea and how it helps with constipation, but it could be worth a try if you aren’t interested in actual medication.

steps.title: Good hydration helps get rid of constipation.
steps.content: Good hydration helps get rid of constipation. While drinking water won’t help you poop instantly, consistent hydration helps your GI tract pass bowel movements much more efficiently. If you’re a guy, make sure you’re drinking around 125 ounces (3.7 L) of water each day; if you’re a woman, aim to drink around 91 ounces (2.7 L). [22] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Some medical professionals find that water with a little lemon juice mixed in can help with constipation. [23] X Trustworthy Source American Cancer Society Nonprofit devoted to promoting cancer research, education, and support Go to source Just slice a fresh lemon in half and squeeze it directly into your glass of water. [24] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
